TinkerCAD is no longer going away in April!.YEA! it's going away in August..sigh.. in celebration? a little Star Trek style ship not based directly on anybody else's design, just one I came up with as I was doodling. three parts- upper and lower ship's hull and upper warp nacelles ( all hail the great Bird of the galaxy, Gene Roddenberry! ) as always ANY comment positive or negative is Greatly appreciated
( how am I going to know if I screwed up if nobody tells me? )

my makerbot is down so if you print this please let me know how it came out its gotta be a while before I'm up and running again and I really want to know how it works.  
the three upper ships hulls primarily differ in ship's bridge although number three has impulse engines added.  Print one each upper and lower hull and one set of upper warp nacelles and glue together....for a bit more of a Picard era look use one of the nacelles to trace on a thin piece of transparent plastic cut out color blue, and place between the upper and lower halves of the nacelles.  I didn't make a piece for the front collectors as I have a red iridescent bead I'm planning to glue in that space

title: Prusa i3 X-Idler & X-Motor with nut traps 'i2 style'

description.text:
UPDATE 15/05/15
I upload this new files:
modulo M5_V3.scad
x-end_V3.scad
x-end-idler_V3.scad
x-end-motor_V3.scad Inter-change position of short & long cut for M5. UPDATE 13/05/15
I upload this new files:
modulo M5_V2.scad
x-end_V2.scad
x-end-idler_V2.scad
x-end-motor_V2.scad Now, the M5 hole is divided in two parts (nut1, nut2 variables): nut1 is the short hole for a fixed M5 nut. Now you can do it a little close and insert nut with iron solder, for example, to fix it. nut2 is the long M5 hole. You can do it a little bigger and allow the other M5 nut to move arround. Same instructions as before. Just change the values for both variables. FIRST DESCRIPTION:
A friend from 'Clone Wars' (spanish reprap group) ask me if I can design X-Idlers with the nut trap like Prusa i2.
It's done.
The source code is from EINSTEIN i3 variant.
I included the source Openscad files & instructions.
The example STL's included was generated from a nut radius value of 4.74mm.
Follow instructions to generate the bests results for you. Not tested yet.

First, print 'modulo M5.stl' and test it.
If you need to change the M5 hole, open file 'modulo M5.scad' and change the value in:
nut =4.74;
Compile & generate your new file & print it.
Whe you find the better value for you, open file 'x-end.scad', change value of "nut" variable & save file.
Then open file 'x-end-idler.scad', compile & generate STL.
Same with 'x-end-motor.scad'.

Anyhow I decided I needed a honey dipper and did not feel like going to the store for one.  My first incarnation copied the traditional format of a stack of disks but that proved hard to print and was a mess using the support material on the Rep 2.  So I worked this up in SolidWorks instead.  Don't put it in the dishwasher!  Enjoy!

I printed it with 3 shells
0.34 layer
30% fill If you are really worried about PLA I imagine you could coat it with a food safe epoxy.

description.text: Icosahedron for kit

This a smaller version of the Pi Box. Many people liked the idea of the original Pi Box, but didn't have a large enough print bed to actually print it. Here is a smaller version that is designed for the Raspberry Pi B+ along with a few variations that will hopefully spice things up. Besides your Raspberry Pi B+ you'll want the following.
External USB hard drive
One SD card (minimum 4GB class 4)
One short panel mounted hdmi cable (978)
One short panel mounted LAN cable (909)
One short panel mounted USB Cable (908)
One short micro usb male female cable extension
One 16mm switch (917)
One 5V 2A micro USB transformer The numbers above in parentheses are part numbers at www.adafruit.com and are given as examples. You can almost always find them cheaper on either Amazon or Ebay. I'd like to warn everyone that I have not printed this. This design is for all the people who liked the Pi Box, but couldn't print it without getting a much larger print base. Any comments or concern would be greatly appreciated.

Print:
1 Base
1 Divider
1 Grill
1 Top
Additionally you can print:
1 Expansion Top
1 Expansion Cover The expansion top and cover are for projects that need additional space. Originally I thought I would use it to house a USB hub and a small fan. Mount the Raspberry Pi B+ and the panel mounted cables. We'll be combining the micro usb extension cable and the power switch so that we can turn the Raspberry Pi on and off using the front button. The female end of the cable will be mounted in the rectangular opening in the back of the box. Measure out enough cable from that end to reach the switch terminals at the front of the box. Strip back the insulation on the cable at that point and cut one of the wires (preferably the positive one if you can...). Now solder those freshly cut ends to the switch terminals. Plug the male end of the cable into the Raspberry Pi. Position the divider and mount the external hard disk to it using double sided foam tape (This not only makes it easier to mount, but also gives the HDD a foam shock absorber. Position the grill and top cover. I've purposefully avoided using any type of fastener (other than foam double sided tape...) to keep the case together because of how inconsistent 3D printed screw threads can be. Enjoy

comments.author: RikhardKarlsson

comments.text: Yes - A full size hard drive is too big for this design and the original Pi Box design as well.  This version of the Pi Box was designed specifically for people with print beds smaller than 200x250mm.  The original Pi Box was designed to be printed on a Maker Gear M2, but most people have some variation of a Replicator (~190x130mm print bed).  This version hopefully will accommodate the needs for those people and make use of the advantages afforded by the Raspberry Pi B+.  With that being said a "full size" (I'm assuming that you mean a 3.5inch drive and that you aren't using 5.25inch or God help you, 8inch drives...) computer hard drive is ~146x100x25mm - without all the necessary adapters to make it work with the Raspberry Pi B+ in the first place.  It just wouldn't make any sense to add a "full size" drive.  Specifically this design calls for an external USB 2.5inch hard drive.  I use a Toshiba 500GB HDTC605XK3A1 (~117x76x13mm) for all my design work - then I add a little wiggle room (The allotted HDD size is ~120x80x15mm).  That's the size of the external housing around the drive and not the drive it's self (~100x70x9mm).  Most newer external USB drive housings are actually smaller than this (My newest Toshiba drive is 107x75x8mm and would require additional padding to keep it from flopping around...)

Wall mount tablet holder - sized here for an 8" Asus Fonepad.  
Allows tablet to be held securely in either landscape or portrait mode, rotating on a threaded rod.   
Important - Please note that this design does not lock, so it's possible to rotate the tablet off the mount!

Print the wall and arm mounts with no support at around 25% infill or greater.  
You may want to slow down printing on these to get a better thread on the connecting rod. I used 30mm/s with no issues, using ABS at 240c.  
The arms should be no more than 15% infill to allow a little flex for installing and removing the tablet. I also suggest using support with these so that the retaining clips don't sag. I found pillars worked well for this.  
The wall mount just needs 4 suitable screws to hold it on the wall.   
The arm mount simply screws onto the wall mounts threaded centre. It will screw down around three full turns onto the wall mount, so once you find the limit, back it off one turn. This will allow you to choose landscape or portrait mode as required - take care when turning anti-clockwise that you don't completely unscrew the arm mount and tablet from the wall mount!

remixed_from.author: selmo
remixed_from.title: Simple Belt Tensioner for Printrbot Jr -- GT2 belts

description.text:
Pivot-Lever One-Piece Gripping One-Screw Tensioner  
Scableable belt tensioner works with a range of belt sizes, in multiple orientations and belt positions.   
Sawtooth teeth on both sides of channel help grip the belt (belt can be installed with teeth facing in or out).  As tension increases on the belt, it pulls the flexible arm into the larger fixed arm, pinching the belt for even better grip.  
ABS is probably better than PLA as the flexibility will help it grip the belt better.  
Requires only one screw, one nut, and one cable tie.

Print and install an 8-32 screw and nut (6-32 will also work).  Only put the screw a little bit into the nut for now.  
Feed the belt loose end through the S-curve and wrap it flat against the teeth on the back of the tensioner.  
Wrap a cable tie around the tensioner (use the slots in the side) and over the loose end of the belt.  
Pinch the flexible arm and the belt loose end into the fixed arm as you tighten the cable tie.  Pull it as tight as you can.  Smaller belts need more cable tie tension to avoid slippage.  
Make sure the pivot is resting against a flat area of the printer body and adjust the screw to increase tension.

  • just have a look at the provided OpenScad screenshots!

    A) the print tolerance as well as the maximum allowed angle is specified not by a parameter but by a single variable at the top of the script

Charge stand for the Pebble Time smart-watch. Still a work in progress. Havent been able make the laser cut or printed bases to test yet (printer broke half way through). Mount has been tested with my Pebble Time watch and fits well, I use it without the base for now since it supports the magnets in the cable which are pretty weak, and keeps it from popping off mid-charge.
I still need to work on the tolerances as it takes a bit of sanding, but with about 5 minutes it will all fit together tightly. Stand uses the charging cable that comes with the Pebble Time, which can be easily inserted and removed from the stand.
Cantilever design allows for charging watches with both open and closed loop bands. Includes 2 versions of a base for laser cutting (wood or acrylic) and 3d printing (fits in my 6x6x6 Printrbot LC with room to spare). Stand is based on Pebble Time exterior and charge cable models from Pebble.
https://github.com/pebble/pebble-3d

Once the charge cable is inserted in to the body of the stand, the cap will slide over the cable and into the grooves on the stand to hold it in place.   
For the current laser cut version, the base is held together with acrylic cement and is glued to the stand. The 3d printed base clips into the top piece, and some glue may be added to make it stronger.

The Milone Sensor should always be kept straigt and protected. Thats why I made these little endcaps to go on a standard drain pipe. The pipe has the following properties:
  • inside diameter 29mm
  • outside diameter 32mm
  • lenght of 220mm
    • Please note:
    The sensor will be 5mm higher from ground. Take this into account when calculating the level.

• get the pipe
  • print the parts
  • stick the Milone sensor in the bottom part first (for best results use some glue on the sides - NOT IN THE MIDDLE OF THE TAPE)
  • Stick the bottom part into the pipe
  • Pull the tape through the top part through the guide
  • make your tests
    • Have fun

When I realized that I needed more tension on my belts I found that standart Y-Motor mount is not strong enough (or not so well designed) to keep its place. It twists and driver gear stop beeing completely aligned. Fortunately i found some old bearings that just fit 5mm inner diameter and I designed a kind of mirror for the standart mount, so motor driveshaft end stay on the bearing and i can fit the belt as much as i need without any issue. Design is for a 16x5x5 bearing and lower screw is replaced by a 15mm one to join with original mount. If you wonder which pulley gear design I use in addition to my design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:740311 Please feel free to update or upgrade, you are welcome!!!

Use a wood piece or some other soft material to press bearing on its place.
Replace original screw (mine was only 8mm) by a longer one but not too much, a 15mm screw will fit great.
Use some nuts and spacers to place both pieces (original and couple) as parallel as possible.

description.text: First off, thanks to Airtripper for a great compact extruder design! This is my J-tripper -- a remix to the Airtripper design to allow for DIRECT mounting of a J-head (or similarlly slotted hot end) to the bottom of the Airtripper direct-drive extruder. I made this design to replace the finicky parts that I encountered on the Mk 7 / QUBD extruder designs. I built mine using a Makerbot MK7 Drive Gear. Visit http://airtripper.com/?p=367 for extruder body build details. Once the extruder body is assembled and mounted to the stepper motor (as in Airtripper's instructions), simply slide the J-head hot-end into the bottom slot. I consider this version "Beta" as I have only been using it for a few days. But it seems reliable so far, so I'm releasing it to the public. As the design is proven and updated to the Airtripper V3 core, I will also release the OpenSCAD file. This is the reference extruder design for the F3 CubeMax (come see us at MakerFaire San Mateo 2013).

Assemble using Airtripper's instructions here:
http://airtripper.com/?p=367 Then slide in your hot end!

author: driggers

description.text:
Buenas tardes,  
Se trata de mi primer desarrollo debido a que no encuentro ninguna que me satisfaga. La caja cuenta con dos ventiladores de 80x80 de 12v que se pueden conectar a molex de la fuente sin necesidad de cortar cables. Es la versión 1.0 y aún no ha sido probada así pues, debería ser la 0. algo xD. He añadido dos bases que se recortan para evitar el warping. Una vez impresa, se van a diseñar enganches para cadenas portacables y sujeciones para los cables.  
Cuenta con una base de 6mm aislada de manera que los tornillos que sujetan la electrónica no tocan el suelo (evitar que al ponerse sobre metal produzca un corto) no tiene perforaciones para ensamblar con el frame, pero se añadirán cuando decida dónde pondré la electrónica.  
También se desea prolongar los leds de la ramps hacia afuera dado que son cómodos para ver conexiones y cuando alimenta; también se barajará la posibilidad de incluir un amperímetro para ver el consumo de la máquina.  
Como se puede apreciar, los soportes del ventilador de la parte posterior sobresalen, eso es así adrede. Falta por diseñar la carcasa superior que tapara los dos coolers; pero hasta que no sea impresa y comprobado sus dimensiones, también está pendiente.   
Espero sirva de ayuda, no dudéis en sugerirme.  
Gracias y saludos

This was originally designed as a joke which went something like this: Now, your already awesome MakerBot can be made even more awesome with mounting brackets for the DIY ClockIt Kit [ http://www.sparkfun.com/products/9205 ]! This way your MakerBot can not only print 3D objects, but tell time! 1 After printing this out, while I was adding it to my bot, I realized that there was a practical use for this, other than the joke. It could be used for time lapse videos for displaying the passage of time, It fits nicely into the upper right of the frame, or a stopwatch for the time your bot has been printing an object. It may be nice to have a custom program for the ClockIt that is more of a stopwatch rather than a clock. I don't know if I will be able to get around to writing one, so if someone is ambitious, go for it!
  • Yes, this idea came from the comment made by MakerBlock on the post "Donâ€™t You Dare Delete That!" at the MakerBot blog [ http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2011/04/19/dont-you-dare-delete-that/ ]. I couldn't add the radio part, but the clock was possible.

Print the brackets out and mount the ClockIt to them with 2x 4-40x~1/2in bolts, I used 4-40x3/4in. Then press the brackets onto the wooden frame on your MakerBot. The power cord for the ClockIt can be fed though the front right hole in your MakerBot.

description.text:
My seven year old is now collecting chess sets. I have a bunch of BNC connectors laying around. So here is a BNC chess set. There are two versions of the pawn.
Skeinforge may complain about the king and or queen, but I ignored the errors and they print fine. I'm not enough of an expert to find and fix the dangling participles. Have fun. Update: added a mock bnc connector for those who are connector deprived. It is not dimensionally correct, nor functional, but it should work as a replacement in this chess set. You probably only need it in the knight, pawn and bishop pieces.

Print the appropriate number of chess pieces. 
Drill the holes out to fit your connectors. 
Insert BNC's into plastic pieces.
Switch colors.
Lather, rinse, repeat.

title: Makerfarm i3v 10" Y-Bed & Y-axis Belt clamp

description.text:
This started out to be a design to make a test part in plastic before having an aluminum bed cut back in December. I put the idea away for a couple of months. My interest was renewed after seeing a thread on the 3dprintboard.com about having a 12" aluminum bed cut. After working thru the design some, I realized that it might actually be possible to make a working plastic y-bed in 2 parts. This is the 1st released version of this design. There is plenty of room for improvements in this design, but for now it suits my needs. I have only done 1 print so far using this new configuration & have not used it with heat. Hopefully the insulation & brass will give it enough support in a heated environment. I used the belt clamping idea from:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:643799 to create my y-axis belt clamp.
I also started to use an idea from an image in this thread http://3dprintboard.com/showthread.php?11867-12-quot-Alum-Y-Plate&p=54207#post54207, but then the design turned into more like a quadcopter design before I added the extra ledge at the ends of the y-axis. 6/4/2015
After printing on this for a few weeks, I have only noticed one problem & that is with my cork insulation. It presses against the binder clips. I moved them about 2.5" to 3" from the corners so they do not affect leveling the bed. If they are between the Wheels and the corner, you can not level the bed very well. The other option would be to cut out the cork around the clips. I still have not printed with heat on the bed yet.

Additional hardware you will need for this are:
6 - M5x18mm socket head bolts & M5 Locknuts
2 - 1/8"x36" Brass rods from Lowes or another source
(2 - 254mm lengths, this might be a little less)
(2 - 190mm lengths)
(2 - 242mm lengths for rods running parallel with the aluminum extrusions)
(Double check these lengths before cutting with hack saw or dremel tool) Parts to Print:
1 YBuildPlate_10inch_Male_rev42_repaired.stl (Rotate 45 degrees in Slic3r program, infill of.6 & infill angle of 22)
1 YBuildPlate_10inch_Female_rev42_repaired.stl (Rotate -135 degrees in Slic3r program, infill of.6 & infill angle of 22)
1 Y-AxisBeltClamp_rev20_repaired.stl (infill of .6 & infill angle of 45)
2 X-AxisSupportPlate_rev4.stl (infill of .6 & infill angle of 45)
(The other stl files are used by the YBuildPlate_10inch_rev42.scad file) I printed in PETG plastic as I was unable to get ABS to print without lifting a corner. I still needed the ears to keep the PETG plastic from lifting.
Print Times for my printing were 5.5 hours for each of the Y-Bed parts, an hour for the Y-Clamp & 48 minutes for the two x-axis supports.
The weight with all the hardware is interestingly enough the exact same as the wooden y-bed with all the hardware, 1 pound even. You can use either M5x18mm socket head screws or M5x16mm socket head screws.
Attached STL files use 18mm long bolts. You will have to uncomment some lines in the openscad file to countersink 16mm bolts in plastic Y-clamp & x-axis supports. You might be able to use M3 bolts for these instead of M5, but you will have to change the hole sizes in the y-Clamp, X-axis supports & the Male & Female Y-Bed. 8mm socket to tighten nuts on the 4 bolts for the x-axis plates works better than an 8mm wrench
8mm wrench works better on the y-carriage Belt clamp. Before taking your printer apart, I would raise the Z axis at least 40 to 50mm to give yourself some room to work.
Make a note of how far the top of your bed is from a known point, like the bottom of the aluminum extrusion. You may have to adjust your Z-limit switch to a different height, since the height of this configuration is a little taller than the original wood frame. Removing old bed
Before removing bed, support the aluminum extrusions on both sides with 2 boards. I used 2 - 2x2x6" boards
Remove the M5 bolts that connect the endplate to the aluminum extrusions.
Mark where your y-axis limit switch is located with a sharpie. This will save you time from readjusting this later
Remove the Y-axis limit switch
remove the belt from the back motor & pull the bed off.
Remove limit switch bolt from wooden plate noting the orientation of the bolt & reinstall in plastic plate as shown in photo
Remove any of the extra plastic from the wheel holes by hand turning a 5/16" bit for the eccentric countersunk holes
& 3/16" bit for the M5 bolts that go on the wheels.
Before leveling your bed
For the rest of the assembly Follow your build guide or the method you used for installing the Y-bed to your i3v. Problems I have noticed.
  • It will flex a little if you press down some at any of the 4 mounting bolt holes. Hopefully the brass will give it enough structure to not be a problem.
  • Binding clips are a bit tight since the bed has a little more height to it. I am using 3/16" thick cork for my insulation on the Y-bed.
  • Eccentric side wheels were at the loosest spot. This was not the case on the 1st test fit. Probably should move each of the 4 wheels out 1mm to allow for adjustment. You can adjust this in the openscad file changing the 2 variables, WheelHoleLt & WheelHoleRt
  • Y-Clamp may be a mm or so off from parallel with belt. I might make this a variable adjustment in a future version of the Y-Clamp openscad file, but does not seem to be a problem so far.
    • There are several other variables you can adjust using the openscad file for the Y-bed.
    Side = 0 or 1 for male or Female side
    BumpSize=9/6 (This is a scale factor for the added bumps, This scale worked well for me)
    DrawEars=1 to draw ears, 0 for no ears (keeps corners from lifting)
    EarHt =.5 (This is the height of ears, .5 worked well for me)
    SagDist=0 (I added this to be able to lift the middle a little, but did not do much for me) You might get better support using 1/8" 6061aluminum round bar, but I do not have any experience using this. Here is a source for the aluminum or Brass Round bar if you can not find it locally. https://www.midweststeelsupply.com/store/6061aluminumroundbar Build thread for this design. http://3dprintboard.com/showthread.php?12018-10-quot-Y-Plate

comments.text: Would this work on the 8"? Or has anyone remixed it for the 8"?
comments.author: traw1234

comments.text: I did not have the key dimensions for a 8" version, but if you know what they are I can update it & you can test it?  I do know now that 148.8mm is the distance between the center line of the Aluminum extrusions, but do not know the hole pattern spacing for the heatbed connection or the distance along the Y-axis of the Wheels.  The wheel distance probably does not need to be exact, but the 4 holes at the corners of the heat bed do.  I used this 10" version for probably over 1000 hours of printing & was still working when I swapped it with the Aluminum bed upgrade a few months ago.  It had a little bit of flex in the corners, but still worked ok.  It just took adjustments to the leveling more often than the aluminum bed.
comments.author: traw1234

comments.text: I've had to update a 12" bed to aluminum. I'd recommend it.
comments.author: Gee_T

comments.text: I have been using this 10" plastic bed since May(over 400 hours). Initially I was not using the heat bed, but printing PLA on a BuildTak surface. For the last month I have been printing the PLA with the heat bed at 60C and is working quite well. I releveled the bed yesterday for the 1st time in over a month & it was hardly off at all. I have not tried printing ABS on it yet, but may at some point. I just put together the Mostly Printed CNC machine http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724999, so I might cut my own aluminum bed at some point or order the aluminum upgrade from Makerfarm. Cost would be less ordering his, but I could cut down a little more weight of the bed if I cut my own.

After we got double glazing in our back door - which needed a thicker external frame - it couldn't open far enough to reach the wind hook anymore.   
So I fixed it with this simple 3D printed Wind Hook Extender!  
Maybe it fits your door, too. Feel free to remix it if it doesn't!

You should naturally print this with 100% infill to make it strong. I chose to print it with (inno)PET material, because PLA seemed a bit brittle for something that needs to withstand wind.  
No raft of support needed - works at any layer height.

They are shorter, more stubby and usually without legs. Automatic support is needed; the model is simple and easy to build with plenty of detail carved in. description.text:
This tripod is a copy of one I have seen at my friends.
Original was a little bit smaller and made with steel pipes. My version uses standard aluminium pipes from a hardware store.
1 pc of 10mm diameter 100 centimeter long (cut into 3 equal pieces) and
1 pc of 20 mm diameter (~45 centimeter long) It folds and its lightweight.

Print one top part, one bottom part and six of the tripods beams.
Take one 10 mm diameter, 100 cm long, aluminum pipe and cut it into 3 about~33cm long pieces.
Drill 5mm diameter hole in one end of each pipe (center of the hole 5mm from end)
Then 95mm from other end of each piece, drill 4mm diameter hole.
Its important that both holes (5mm dia and 4mm dia) were in the same direction (parallel).
take the 20mm diameter pipe and put bottom part on it, screw the screws into aluminium through the holes (I used 3 small self tapping screws)
i assume that the rest of assembly is quite obvious, if not, I will update this description immidiately. BOM:
3 pc 10mm diameter aluminium pipe 330mm long.
1 pc 20mm diameter aluminium pipe 450mm long (more or less i used scrap piece so I don't know the exact length)
5 pcs M5 25mm hex screw
1 pc M5 35mm hex screw (for tightening)
5 pcs M5 Hex self locking nuts
1 pc M5 hex nut ( for printed knob)
3 pcs M3 25mm screw
3 pcs M3 hex nut
Bunch of washers 3mm and 5mm

title: M2 Dual Extruder for M2 and E3D

description.text:
This is my latest design for a dual extruder for my M2. This time I designed it for the E3D V6 hotend. I wanted the ability to use the continuous PTFE tube from the drive gear to the hotzone of the E3D. I am hoping this helps me print flexible filament better. I was hoping to reduce the weight by moving one of the extruders off the gantry as a Bowden.
I did not like the idea of bolting the e3d in from the bottom so I designed this split arrangement.
The benefit I see in this design is that; The hotend is fixed relative to the gantry and does not rotate or shift; you can feed and remove the filament very easily; it has the most continuous support of the filament I have seen is a direct drive; it is easy to clear jams if they occur.
I am still thinking of better ways for a the tensioning system. It works now but you have to have a feel for how tight you need it and there is variability each time you redo it.
I would love to hear what people think of this design. Here is a video that goes over some details.
https://youtu.be/qAHeEA26nSM I have a single hotend version here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:824655

The bearings are the standard size that came with the machine. The bolts that hold the bearing are 5x18 and I used a regular nut with no washers. The two bolts that lock the stepper in place are 4x whatever fits, a 18mm should work. Make sure to replace the x axis end switch stop or the extruder will run into the left side. There are changes that will need to be made to the firmware but those are different depending on how old your M2 is. I would recommend checking out the MakerGear forum for more info on what needs to be changed in the firmware.   
I first printed this in PLA but the stepper got to hot and started deforming the motor mount. i then tried ABS but I do not have much experience in ABS and could not get it to print without delaminating. This was likely user error. I then printed it in PET+ and it works beautifully. The blue one in the pictures was done in PETG and it printed well.  
I am going to upload the bowden extruder that accompanies this as a separate Thing and will update the link here. I will also be uploading a single hotend version that is based off this design.

comments.text: Ilike your design. It is very innovative. Very practical also the way you take out the hotend, and the motor. Congrats
comments.author: Ybm

author: AwesomeA

description.text:
This is my contribution to the Video goggles section on thingiverse.
The design is based on the VR Goggles you can find here
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:752547 I completly remodeled them in sketchup to implement the features I needed, for example a wider form factor for my glasses.
The goggles has 2 fresnellenses ([frɛˈnɛl]) which are positioned just right for my eyes.
I made some tests with friends and family which had problems using the goggles caused by the sense distance. I uploaded the sketchup file so you can make corrections as needed. I recommend to make yourself some sort of testing rig to first of all check which lense distances are best for you. The goggles were made for a 4,3" monitor. UPDATE 07/08/15:
I added a frames for the fresnel lenses if yours is more on the thinner side. UPDATE 18/08/15: Now not only FPFree but also free from tangled wires. I am working on a guide to use a rc 305 to make this a standalone unit. The guide will be posted on my website, so feel free to have a look and follow me on instagram for the latest updates. http://firefly1504.myfreesites.net https://instagram.com/firefly_1504/

(Needs to be printed in ABS. If you want to follow my these instructions. If you print in PLA you need a good CA to glue the peaces together) Print the video goggles.stl and the monitor mount.stl You need to print the rectangle in the monitor mount twice.
After you got all your bits and peaces. Sand it down an give it a coat of acetone. Then glue the monitor mount pieces onto the goggle in the right distance for your monitor.
I added some foam into the monitor mount to press it firmly against the goggle. I also used form for the front and 40mm elastic strap from eBay.

description.text:
All my models are printed on a Prusa i3 kit. You can find the one I use by clicking the link below. You can get 15% off by using code "GBTE"

remixed_from.author: jprikkel
remixed_from.title: Ultimate 50mm Rotating Spool Holder - MakerBot Replicator 2

title: Spool Roller for Rostock Max v2

description.text:
This thing is a spool roller adapter for a Rostock Max v2. It uses the spool rollers from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119016. I made this because I use spooled filament with 50mm center bores and this just works! The new adapter fits securely in the same position as the stock spool arm. And, yes, this allows the user of the larger spools from Makerbot. You know, the ones that don't fit your Rep1 or Rep2 anymore. :P NOTICE:
This .scad file requires the spool arm .stl file from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213252. Be sure to download that first, rename it Spool_arm.stl then place this .scad file in the same folder before compiling.

Vitamins:
(1) 5/16"x5-1/4" bolt (6" inch will work but will stick out a bit)
(2) 5/16" washers
(1) 5/16" Nylock
//
Instructions:
  • Print the adapter on its end using supports. Clean out the supports.
  • Print the 50mm roller from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119016
  • Insert the bolt through the adapter and add the washers.
  • Insert the roller over the bolt and thread the Nylock.
  • Tighten until the roller doesn't slide back and forth but still
    rolls freely.
    • Note: you can print any size roller you want provided it is the same height as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119016 and has a 5/16" bore. Roller should not bind on the bolt.

description.text:
This belt clamp replaces the wooden belt clamp that is underneath the original Makerfarm 10" Y-bed. Use the same M3x25mm bolt with locknut, but other 2 bolts & nuts are not needed. There are 2 main variables you can change in the openscad file,
BeltGap=19; //Distance between top of belt & bottom of Y-bed
SocketOrNut=0; //0 = countersink for RoundSocket or 1 = countersink for Locknut. I used the 19mm RoundSocket countersink, but probably could have gone to 17mm.
I created this part in case my Y-Bed idea did not work as I got tired of cutting wire ties & replacing them. I used the belt clamping idea from:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:643799 to create this part.
Print which ever stl file configuration you like, or adjust the openscad file to suit your needs.

author: pomaaa

title: HYREL EMO Extruder Printable nozzle adapter

description.text:
Our lab has a HYREL 3D Printer with an EMO-25 paste extruder (25 being for the version that holds 25mL of paste).
They came with relatively large nozzles (1-2mm) to print clay or other pastes with, but we needed to use a small nozzle (<0.5mm).
We decided to make a version with an adapter to fit luer lock tapered tips or needles (anything with a luer lock, easy to find - http://www.ebay.com/itm/like/251510342242?lpid=82&chn=ps)
The tapped hole fits #10-32 thread where you screw in an adapter (mcmaster part # 51465k151, http://www.mcmaster.com/#51465k151/=x5iczg).
A 15mm ID, 17mm OD (1mm thick) o-ring from amazon (http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00595IBKC/ref=biss_dp_t_asn) is required to seal to the tube.
A 3mm ID, 5mm OD (1mm thick) o-ring from amazon (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008JBW7ZS/ref=ox_sc_act_title_3?ie=UTF8&psc=1&smid=A1THAZDOWP300U) is required to seal the luer adapter. I'm working on a variant that uses the same o-ring that the plunger uses on the actuating side (fewer parts/can replace both with the same stock wen they wear out)

UPDATE 5 May 2013
Pictures and Video added of my final printed /currently in use model of this fan mount.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xbkP642g6Q8 2 May 2013
Everything has been tweaked / Is in the process of being tweaked. it works fantastically for my Antec fan and the holes are able to be threaded with the fan screws I had leftover from the power supply. Its just the mounting and the angle in which the fan is going that are problematic. I made the "clip" on the hanger a closed design as i was having problems with it staying seated. 1 May 2013 I had a bad power supply given to me, with a couple good 80mm fans in it, so I decided to finally figure out a better solution to my cooling conundrum. Enter Tinkercad, an 80mm fan STL file, and some digital calipers. I split the hanger and fan mount up for two reasons; one being that my Z carriage is warped on my printer, so until I print new pieces for that my measurements will be different (most likely) than everyone elses. Secondly so that anyone may design themselves a mount that can be used with their 80mm fan... I am literally in the process of printing this right now, thus far the fan measurements seem solid, although i don't know if the clip-in "wrap around" style will work properly... I printed the hanger portion that fits over the Z carriage first - fits perfectly! NOTE: the Fan hanger has an angle to the mounting portion so to aim the fan down slightly toward the print bed. If any further alterations to this should be done, please let me know. ALSO NOTE: The Fan Hangar appears to function okay by itself, albeit a tad high and the mounting is unrefined, but it will function that way regardless... That's your fun fact for the day. Work in progress (What isn't) So check back soon for a follow-up! Cheers.

I am printing in Gray PLA from JUSTPLA - @ 220  
I recommend printing the Z carriage hanger first to test its fit on your machine, or measure your carriage and gap. measurements from my piece are 6.15mm for 1st gap, 8.15 for the middle bar, 6.25 for the 2nd gap.  
print the first few layers, measure - modify or scale if need be and finish! - I'll let you know how the fan mount functions soon...

title: Modern Elements
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Another [ C60 buckyball / truncated icosahedron / soccer-ball ] lamp. The facets on this one are designed to shade the lamp bulb only when viewed directly, and otherwise be transparent to the inside of the lamp. This effect was generally successful but less impressive than I expected. The first design ( modern_pentagon, modern_hexagon, baffel ) had these flaws :
-- weak, flexible walls made hinges hard to manage
-- impossibly tight hinges ( required removing a lot of plastic )
-- weak supports for the light-diffusing inner panels; The lamp pictured was built with the original design. However, I updated the design ( modern_pentagon_revised, modern_hexagon_revised, baffel_revised ) to attempt to correct these three problems. I would print and test the hinge fit for the revised pieces, I expect them to be stronger and easier to work with, but there may be unexpected problems. You can also tweak the parameters in the .scad file yourself.

Print 12 pentagons and 19 hexagons. Using a hobby knife, remove the stabilizing material from the hinges. If necessary, also clean out stray plastic within the hinges. Using a well calibrated machine with oozebane or a stepper extruder will simplify clean-up of the hinges. If hinges do not mate easily and securely, trim the bumps on the hinges down with a knife. Preferably, adjust the design in scad until the hinges mate easily. Assemble a soccer-ball shaped sphere, leaving one hexagon out. As I used the original pieces, this was extremely difficult and required thinning out the hinges by hand quite a bit. Perhaps the revised parameters will make it easier. Build http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7857 Add the final hexagon piece ( bottom of print facing outside ) to complete the geodesic sphere. Note that only the smallest of the commercial CFL light-bulbs fit into the shade. note on hinge clearance : The hinges can sometimes be a little tight. Make sure the first layer isn't pressed too far into the build platform. A compressed first layer will propagate up and make part of the hinge wider, decreasing the clearance. These parts are designed to fit tightly and may require pliers to assemble. If all else fails, removing some of the pins on the hinges can make assembly easier.

description.text: Setting the levels on the two extruders is fiddly and in the original design these levels are lost if you loosen the clamp to remove one or both of the extruders. The Height Setting Arm allows you to fix these levels so you can remove and replace the extruders without having to re-level. Additionally it offers a second support for the extruders taking pressure off the existing clamp. A retrofit part for the existing design will be made available and will be incorporated in the next iteration of the design (see RigidWiki). Thank you to Michael Forte for coming up with this clever solution.

Just another phone holder that will enable you to make video calls with ease. It really works for most any models.
It also holds a pen inside the holder. The pen you see there has a touch screen end thingimajig.

I printed this item with the fine print setup and I think 100% infill. And off course on its side.
If you put the phone on its side as well you can charge it. Then back up it goes.
Might want to put some double sided tape on the bottom of the feet since it will slide accross your desk a bit. If you have a rubber printer, problem solved lol. I made a Wide version for those who have their case on the phone all the time. Basically I made the base of the phone a bit wider, by like 4mm. It should accomodate even the thickest of cases. Do let me know and post pics since I didn't print that version yet. I also made one with a friend name on the front foot, which can fit about 5 letters at 22 font size. But I suggest a good printer for that since the spacing is small. The cad files are up there to modify.

comments.text: I think its best to print the Wide version. Fits a phone with or without a cover just as well.

title: laser cut Cool Runner 2 Cpld.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: laser cut cool runner 2 case made at the PCC maker space.

assembly:  
designed to use 3/4" 4-40 nylon hardware, I used counter sunk heads (requires countersinking the faceplate with a drill press),  other style heads are acceptable (just make sure they are long enough).  
material is 1/8th" or 3mm baltic birch plywood and 1/8th" or 3mm acrylic and thin card stock.  
the shim should be glued to the bottom side of layer 3 so that is aligns with the shape, this will hold the cpld in place. any glue is acceptable i.e. super glue/wood glue etc....  
the base acrylic sheet should be glued to the first sheet of plywood. assemble the stack and screw together, then remove the acrylic baseplate, use small dabs of superglue spaced about 2mm from the nuts and also at the midway points between each corner and on the span that runs down the center. press acrylic baseplate onto the case to adhere.  
note: the rubber feet on your cpld will need to be removed to use this case, but good news everyone, they are perfectly suited as feet for your new cpld case, simply stick them on the bottom of your assembled case.   
Variations, this can also be made with all acrylic or all wood.

author: liljimmisticles
